Award.AwardTitle: Mechanism of Homologous Recombination in Archaea

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Homologous recombination is a major mechanism for repair of double-strand breaks caused by exposure to chemical mutagens and radiation. Repair of these breaks is an evolutionary imperative and ensures proper transfer of information from generation to generation without information loss. General understanding of this process has come mostly from studies from the bacterial or eukaryotic branches of life. Very little is known about double-strand break repair in the third, archaeal branch. Archaea physically resemble bacteria, but use some cellular approaches to life that seem to be more eukaryotic. Key among these eukaryotic-like processes are methods of genome maintenance, including double-strand break repair. This provides a unique opportunity to study homologous recombination mechanisms in an evolutionarily distinct group of organisms. The overall objective of this project is to use the well established archaeal model Sulfolobus solfataricus to determine the mechanistic role of three proteins that are related by sequence to the strand-exchange protein, RadA. The research on these paralogues will involve graduate, undergraduate, and high school students using two complementary but independent approaches: 1) Biochemical activity of the proteins in vitro will be determined individually and in combination with other known recombination-related proteins, where their interactions and point of function in the repair pathway will be established; 2) Roles of the paralogues in vivo will be assessed through studies of protein persistence after radiation damage and measurement of chromosomal repair rates in both wild-type and mutant strain backgrounds.

This project focuses on a mechanism necessary for cellular survival following DNA damage in a member of the least well studied branch of life. In addition to understanding more about the way in which all cells repair their DNA, this work is expected to provide new overall insight into the regulation of homologous recombination and maintenance of genome stability. These studies are multidisciplinary, using biochemical, genetic, and cellular approaches that will provide a broad laboratory education for students at various educational stages. Specifically, this project provides laboratory training for one graduate and two undergraduate students, with a special emphasis on outreach recruiting of underrepresented minority students. Additionally, two high school students will be supported through summer internships, which will offer a valuable research experience to young scientists at early stages in their careers.

POR.DRECONTENT: One of the most dangerous forms of damage to our DNA is through breaks, and when breaks occur across both strands it can be particularly lethal. Cells are very efficient at repairing breaks and a main approach for fixing this damage is through an evolutionarily conserved process known as recombination. When something goes wrong during recombination, though, it can lead to cell death or development of disease. Understanding the way in which eukaryotic cells use recombination to repair breaks has been difficult because these types of organisms are significantly more complex than bacterial species that have been commonly used as models. The third, archaeal branch of life offers an opportunity for new perspectives on how our cells work, particularly for highly conserved processes. How these single celled microbes handle recombination-based DNA repair is especially interesting because the proteins involved are remarkably similar to those of eukaryotes. The number of proteins, however, is dramatically smaller, giving us an opportunity to study the process at the simplest level.  Our work has focused on using the archaeon Sulfolobus as a model to learn how cells handle DNA recombination. In particular we have examined the role of three proteins that are related by sequence to the main strand exchange protein, but whose purpose in the process was unknown. Our investigations used the complementary approaches of cellular function and biochemical activity to determine the role of these proteins in recombination. We found that after suffering DNA damage from either UV or ionizing radiation, Sulfolobus cells respond by increasing production of the transcripts that encode these proteins and proceed to repair the breaks. The timing for transcript production correlates closely with break repair, indicating that these proteins are important for fixing the damage. We also found that the increase in transcription is transient, which demonstrates that the cell can carefully control production of these proteins and only make them when needed to repair DNA. While this information told us that the proteins were invovled in repair, we still did not know how they affected the process. To understand their function in recombination, we turned to direct examination of the proteins using biochemical approaches. We developed a variety of biochemical assays that could determine how these three proteins participate in the progression of recombination. Using these assays, we found that two of these proteins, Ral1 and Ral3, are important for early steps in recombination and assist the strand exchange protein during its search for homologous sequences. The third protein, Ral2, influences the efficiency of recombination by direclty interacting with the Ral1 and Ral3 proteins and controlling their activity. The significance of this research has been not only in basic scientific discovery, but also in the training of the next generation of scientists. Over the duration of this work, 6 high school students, 15 undergraduates, and 2 graduate students have been trained in basic molecular and microbiological techniques as well as biochemistry. Of particular note, Goldwater scholarships have been earned by two students who worked on the project; one of these students was a high school student while the other was an undergraduate. Of the undergraduates, several have made significant contributions to the research and will be co-authors on upcoming manuscripts. Of the graduate students, one has completed his dissertation and gone on to a postdoctoral position in the DNA repair field, while the other is preparing additional manuscripts about the activities of these recombination proteins.
